name: cercis-canadensis-flame-thrower
wildlife-value: 12 species of Lepidoptera use this tree as a larval host plant. Host plant for Henry's Elfin butterfly. Caterpillars appear from February to May and have one flight. Bees will visit the flowers for nectar and pollen. Birds will eat the seeds
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: In summer through fall and even winter, this plant has green turning to brown, flat, oblong seedpods (with about 5-9 seeds per pod) which are about 2 to 4 inches long.
flower-description: Pea-shaped light purple flowers appear in clusters in April before leaf-out and grow directly on new and old stems. Individual flowers are 1/2 inch across
leaf-description: Simple, alternate heart-shaped leaves, 3 to 5.5 inches long and wide, with smooth, entire margins. Bases are cordate, acute apex, with swelling on petioles just underneath the leaf plate. 7 palmate veins extend from the leaf base. Leaves transition from purple to red to reddish-bronze and ultimately yellow-green. Attractive yellow fall color.
bark-description: Dark brown to black with orange inner bark that can be visible. Smooth when young, but developing long, narrow plates that separate into scales as the tree matures.
stem-description: Slender, glabrous, dark reddish brown to black, zig-zag, spreading and ascending.
